div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, May 26, 1901
div1.p:
We note with interest the fact that
Surgeon General Sternberg's circular does
not carry the mosquito hypothesis quite
so far, in connection with yellow fever, as
have done so many of his less experi-
enced but more optimistic subordinates.
He says:

“The recent experiments made in Havana by the
medical department of the army having proved that
yellow fever, like malarial fever, is conveyed chiefly
and probably exclusively by the bite of infected
mosquitoes, important changes in the measures used
for the prevention and treatment of this disease
have become necessary.”

Presumably, Dr. Sternberg does not re-
fer to the case of the individual patient
when he speaks of “important changes
in the measures used for the prevention
and treatment of this disease.” It has
not transpired that the symptoms of the
patient have undergone any important
modification since the announcement of
the mosquito theory, and we assume,
therefore, that the yellow fever victim
will be handled pretty much in the future
as he has been in the past. It is easy to
see, however, that an adoption of this
theory will necessarily involve radical
amendments in the treatment of the mal-
ady itself. Indeed, this seems to be the
meaning of the next paragraph in the
circular:

“So far as yellow fever is concerned, infection of
a room or building simply means that it contains
infected mosquitoes--that is, mosquitoes which have
fed on yellow fever patients. Disinfection, there-
fore, means the employment of measures aimed at
the destruction of these mosquitoes. The most ef-
fective of these measures is fumigation, either with
sulphur, formaldehyde, or insect powder. The
fumes of sulphur are the quickest and the most ef-
fective insecticide, but are otherwise objectionable.
Formaldehyde gas is quite effective if the infected
rooms are kept closed and sealed for two or three
hours. The smoke of insect powder has also been
proved useful; it readily stupefies mosquitoes, which
drop to the floor and can be easily destroyed.”

In other words, there is to be an end
to the foolish and mischievous supersti-
tions of the past; to most of the bar-
barities of quarantine, maritime and in-
land; to the brutal paralysis of commerce,
and the horrors of the shotgun cordon.
The Southern States will--at léast in time
--rid themselves of the swarms of petty
local officials, salaried chiefly to the end
of working material injury to the tax-
payers. Business, travel, the transporta-
tion of the mails, &c., will be conducted
on lines that run parallel with enlight-
ened civilization. Yellow fever will be
taken out of politics and handed over to
the custody of science. Surely, a blessed
and most welcome consummation!

To such of our esteemed contemporaries
--and these are chiefly Southern contem-
poraries, as is natural enough, since the
North and West take only an academic
interest in the subject--to such of these
as have seen fit to ridicule or to antag-
onize Dr. Sternberg's postulate, we beg
to suggest that the Surgeon General has
at no time declared the mosquito to be
either the original cause of yellow fever
or its only possible vehicle of transmis-
sion. Neither, as we understand him, does
he prophesy that the conditions now
known to prevail at Havana, where yel-
low fever is indigenous, will necessarily
be exactly reproduced in this country,
where it is exotic. But it has been dem-
onstrated that yellow fever is always
communicable by mosquitoes, and that it
is never communicated by personal con-
tact; and upon these ascertained facts
the Surgeon General is abundantly war-
ranted in setting up the propositions we
have quoted from his circular.
